Thing is, that recording of Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville’s voice in 1860… well, he never heard it. The phonautograph, the device he made to record voices, only wrote down their sound wavelengths to a sheet of paper. There was no way for him to play the audio back, unlike with Alexander Graham Bell’s invention years later. We’re only able to hear that recording because people in 2008 stumbled across the paper and used the written wavelengths to reproduce the sound digitally.

Actually, your blood wouldn't boil and you wouldn't inflate, air would rush out of your lungs, and if you tried to hold your breath, they might rupture. Your blood pressure is sufficient to keep body-temperature blood from boiling and would simply increase if it weren't.
There was an actual case where someone was rapidly exposed to zero-pressure conditions and they blacked out almost immediately due to hypoxia. When they awoke after being moved back to normal air, they said that they remembered their saliva boiling. This can also happen in atmosphere above the "Armstrong Limit" of ~19 kilometers. Any unpressurized water (such as saliva, or at a slightly higher altitude, blood exposed to open air) will start boiling away as a gas and if it boils away quickly, it will also generate ice. (note that this means an unpressurized military plane at 20 km would allow cups of water to boil rapidly.)
Also, the freezing temperatures would be a non-issue in space. Just don't leave the sunlight for more than about 8 hours and you should be fine.

By the way, don't think that you can just go sending probes straight through any part of Saturn's rings. A direct collision with the B-ring even at fairly insiginificant speed, for example, would be like trying to run a spacecraft through another spacecraft. Colliding retrograde with the B-ring could vaporize a 1000-kilometer-wide icy moon.

An extreme oversimplification:

Microphone contains a small section called a diaphragm. This vibrates as sound hits it. Other components in the microphone use the vibrations to modulate an electric current to have peaks and valleys that (sort of) match the pattern of the sound wave.

This signal can be transmitted directly to a speaker which will vibrate to match the original recording, reproducing the sound.

Or, the wave can be digitized and stored for future playback.

You would simultaneously freeze and boil to death. This actually has nothing to do with the temperature, but with the pressure. The lower the pressure on a substance, like water, the closer together the freezing and boiling point become. In space, because there is absolutely no pressure, the freezing and boiling point cross, causing liquid water to freeze and or boil, but would be unable to stay a liquid. Since most of the human body is water, the same thing would likely happen.

The 2000 4000 Hz range of human speech are sounds of the consonants in language.  The consonants breakup the vowel tones we make and this creates discrete phonemes.  We learn the meaning of these phonemes which gives meaning to language.  Since hearing loss in most older people is actually a desensitization of perception of the higher ranges, like in the 2000-4000 Hz range, they have a hard time hearing the consonants that are being spoken.
